question: I can't look.
answer: Good idea, let's not.

question: How can we not listen to this?
answer: We'll know all we need to from the reaction.

question: I took it all down over the phone. It's quite bad. And, unfortunately, it's very, very long. I've got a broken heart and writers' cramp. He...
answer: He's nuts.

question: He savages everyone.
answer: I don't want to hear anymore. Let's dance.

question: Sorry.
answer: Will you get in here--for God's sake?

question: Come on, Ma, how could I show up tonight when my union is boycotting the Emmys? Look, I have to hang up.
answer: It's on right now... right now... right this second! You will miss it!!

question: I gotta go. Watch!
answer: Shit! Fuck! Shit!

question: He was good.
answer: Shit! Shit! Shit! Fuck! Shit! Look, he even showed up.

question: That took courage. I wonder if they send you something for just being nominated?
answer: Of all the pathetic questions.

question: Why are you being so damn foul?
answer: We've been going back and forth on our status for so long. I was hoping that if you won, it might mean something for us.

question: Look, Beth... the only...
answer: Please go fast. I can't take you dragging it out.

question: The only reason I haven't...
answer: I promised myself I wouldn't be so bossy. Take your time!! Was that bossy too?

question: The only thing I have against getting married is that it might not be fair because I'm going to stay with acting forever and you know how erratic the money's been and there's no resolve...
answer: Do I get to vote? I'm going to tell you something I never told you before. Your feeling towards your work is one of the things I love most about you.

question: Really?
answer: Maybe the most.

question: Hey, then we have no problem here. Marry me.
answer: Stinker, I almost gave up on you.

question: I was just worried whether I could make you happy. Everything's okay... Great... She's six or eight pounds even. Oh, God... Nothing like it. I'll tell you something amazing. They really reach right into her stomach and pull out this baby. It's not just a rumor. God. I understand the expression 'mind blowing' for the first time. It means something so wonderful happens that the top of your head comes off and your brain pops out. Part of it was terrifying, the baby was turned and they couldn't budge her. I kept looking at this one woman doctor's eyes. And when Jeannie finally came out, this doctor and I each wiped away a tear at the exact same time, caught ourselves doing it, and then laughed together at the same time. Nothing can prepare you for it. You know why you're alive. How you doing? What's wrong?
answer: My mother said you were flirting with the doctor during the delivery.

question: Could you get her, honey? I have that big reading tomorrow.
answer: No, I have a lot to do tomorrow, too. I have to borrow on our Christmas Club, I have to...

question: Don't worry about money anymore. I didn't want to tell you, because it may sound a little strange when I say it out loud. You know me, I'm never that cocky. But I'm going to get 'Spider Woman'. It's me or Raul and I've never been so sure. It's weird, but I just know it. I do.
answer: Boy, am I reassured. What good news. Isn't that a load off?

question: I am gonna get this part, Beth.
answer: I can't stand this anymore.

question: Hi... See, I did recognize you. You didn't have to wait for me.
answer: Well, I wanted to introduce you. As if knowing me would help. It's a ridiculously awful movie.

question: Well, challenge. I wasn't sure you'd remember me... let alone help...
answer: Stop. You're good. I'm doing them a favor by getting you in.

question: Well, that's a fresh slant.
answer: Claire, this is Matt Hobbs.

question: So, what have you been doing with yourself... ...the last few years?
answer: I'm real bad at interviews, so, if you don't mind, I'd really prefer to just read first.

question: That's the way you want to do it?
answer: Yes.

question: Maybe we shouldn't even read. I'll just take your word that you're good. No. I'm serious. There's all different ways. Did you know Woody Allen never reads actors? He just looks at them, feels around a little and then decides who he wants. That's his way. Doesn't hear them do a line. I also have a way. What I do is interview first-- then read--maybe do it all over again the next day. I call up people the actor has worked with--check him out. If he's famous, I do an opinion survey to test how much people like him. If he's not famous, I put him on tape and show it to everyone I can grab. I believe in screen tests; I believe in replacing if the dailies are bad, in cutting people out if the previews aren't there. Because I'm not doing movies for theaters where they serve cappucino in the lobby. I'm doing popcorn movies. You want to know what I like? Come to my house, look at my lamps... you won't find it in my movies. In my movies, you'll find out what I know. I know how to do detail. What I don't know, I discover. Yesterday we finished mixing a movie--the last scene is in a field of windmills which blows up and all the blades of these windmills slice through the air, one of which hits a four-story tank of propane gas. A humongous explosion scene. I kept on saying 'louder', and they finally said to me they couldn't go louder without distortion. We went louder. We had to discover a thing, a filter, but we went louder. I don't question doing these things. I do them. So if you want to know if it's okay to do it differently--not to talk--to just read first... I say... Ask him--he's the director. Okay, let's do it. Do you have any questions?
answer: They only gave me these two pages. I'd like to give this my best shot. So if I could read the script and come back...

question: This part works tomorrow.
answer: Oh. Who will I be reading with? Can I read from here?

question: I want you to do it wherever you're comfortable, but I'd prefer it if you were comfortable standing up. Go ahead.
answer: Go ahead? The director left.

question: That's okay, he trusts me, uh... And we're just doing the first page.
answer: 'Incredibly drawn out...' 'Well, what am I? Your duck?' 'We've been together two years and you act like all you're doing is blowing away some feathers. So what I'm asking...'

question: You didn't do the quack.
answer: Huh?

question: The stage direction says for him to quack.
answer: I know, but why would he quack when someone's breaking up with him?

question: Hopefully because it's funny.
answer: This isn't a comedy.

question: Then we're in trouble, because they're already fall down laughing at the teaser-trailer in fifty-two hundred and thirty theaters.
answer: A comedy? I think I have to make an adjustment here.

question: Story, story, story, story, story. You loved it, right?
answer: I had some problems.

question: Like what?
answer: Well, you know, it's a little garbagey.

question: Hey. It's not like I didn't recommend it. How'd it go?
answer: I didn't get it. He did say something about wanting me back.

question: Good. His saver is he means what he says.
answer: Yeah, I just wanted to say thanks. ...and I wanted to ask you out.

question: For when?
answer: Any time.

question: I never know when I'm free. It sounds like I'm just... but it's true.
answer: Okay. Thanks again. I felt funny asking.

question: Well, don't please.
answer: I meant asking you to get me the audition.

question: Oh, God... why? Why?... What am I going to do?
answer: Hey. Hey! HEY!!

question: Look at me. You'd think I was a writer. I hired this kid as a production assistant. His father's a business manager... a few good clients.
answer: What happened?

question: He's been driving for me two weeks... all he has to do is pick me up on time... he's twenty minutes late and I have a test screening in the valley. Everybody's gone from the office.
answer: Is that it? You need a lift?

question: Yeah.
answer: I'm right over here.

question: ...Not just today... believe me, there's no way you'll ever make it... You are going to fail. Listen, listen-- I know about this; you are going to be a failure. Let's get moving; you said you'd give me a lift.
answer: What the hell are you talking about? Not in your car... I've got my own.

question: I'll give you a hundred and twenty dollars to take me... and it will still be a favor. Get out. Come on. Please. This is very important. You should leave time for that kind of thing.
answer: What do you need me for? Don't you drive?

question: Yeah, I drive. I don't like to look for parking. Yoga shit. I feel like barbed wire. I don't know if you keep track, but I'm the sixth independent producer ever to have two big pictures scheduled for Christmas, and tonight we're testing the first one for the first time... You get it?
answer: Yeah. It's important to you.

question: How long since you've seen your daughter?
answer: A little over two years. My wife insisted on moving back to the Midwest--then I was in the Philippines on the mini-series and...

question: Oh, please. It's one thing being a son-of-a-bitch, but you don't have to be a stupid son-of-a-bitch. People move heaven and earth to see their kids. I don't care if she moved to Pluto, it's abandonment.
answer: Hey, we just met.

question: Oh. Sorry.
answer: Make a guess how we did.

question: It wouldn't mean anything.
answer: Nothing good that happens can make it worth feeling the way I do now. Nothing. Who the hell are you? This is private. Oh. Can I get you some water?

question: Burke, ninety in the top two boxes.
answer: Now can I get you some water?

question: I never thought it would do this well. There were so many holes; I told everybody it wasn't going to do business. Why am I so public with my opinions?
answer: You might be right.

question: Not with that score. You know, maybe tonight's the night I'm losing my entire mind, but weren't you in 'Platoon?'
answer: Incredible. I was only there for a minute in the rape scene, moving past Charlie Sheen when I left the hut... I had a great scene cut out... I was...

question: But there was that one long close up-- where you seemed ashamed of yourself but still arrogant.
answer: That's exactly what I was going for.

question: It reminded me of my last boyfriend. Got to go.
answer: You have to read all that?

question: Beast of burden.
answer: So what are you, totally wonderful or what?

question: How come you haven't said anything? This is great, right?
answer: No.

question: What no?
answer: The definite recommends are way off for a score this high and, even for action-adventure, it's just too low for women. I'm sorry.

question: It was such a good score.
answer: I know... And, unfortunately, yesterday's tracking wasn't... I'm sorry... They just don't seem in the mood for action-adventure right... Sorry... May I tell you one more thing? I think it's so wonderful that you don't worry about even trying to act strong.

question: Thanks. You want to eat something sometime?
answer: I'm, uh... I'm blushing from head to foot.

question: Okay, I got the cards to look at--I think I'll ride back here. Maybe I'll drop by your place tomorrow.
answer: So, thanks for lunch. I hope this leads to an evening date. Though I have to stay home with my daughter, Leslie, on Saturdays.

question: Yeah, okay. You were very interesting to talk to. I swear to God. Honest. No kidding. You really were.
answer: I believe you. And I was very surprised what you were like when you weren't working. There was absolutely no difference. You want to see where we do the tracking?

question: Is it okay?
answer: Nobody ever wants to see how we do the polling, but they're like little starved puppies when the data comes in--running at you, scrambling to...

question: I love this. This is what counts and this is where you count it.
answer: That's the same way I feel.

question: You phone all over--you know what movies they're waiting to see, whether your TV spots are working. You know what the country thinks. ...and it's accurate.
answer: Within six-point-eight percent.

question: And you can't fix it... right?
answer: No... no... Sometimes just for myself, I can't resist asking America a personal question.

question: Like?
answer: When do you feel more worthless-- mornings or afternoons?

question: I gotta get back.
answer: There's something I meant to tell you. You may have noticed something unusual about me.

question: I gotta get back.
answer: I could never find the right time to...

question: Is this urgent?
answer: Well, maybe not urgent, but immediately significant and necessary to tell. You see, there's these pills...

question: 'Cause I gotta go. I'm listening with an eighth of an ear now.
answer: So long.

question: Hello--did you two meet?
answer: Not really. Is she ready? I have the taxi waiting.

question: I just have to say goodbye. You have no idea how difficult that is.
answer: It's three weeks.

question: It's not three weeks.
answer: Yes, it is.

question: No, it's not.
answer: It is.

question: What? I'm giving Jeannie her reminders.
answer: Reminders?!? You can't say things like that to a little...

question: No. Don't. No. Don't dare. Don't criticize the way I mother or I think I'll start to scream and never st... Yes. You're not going to criticize me, are you? Not in front of him--because all he's done is send Jeannie these long, stupid letters. He doesn't even realize she can't read. He sends letters to someone who can't read. It's almost funny.
answer: I thought you'd read them to her.

question: Oh. Typical cop talk. But I understand what you're trying to say. Thank you. Can I have another minute with her?
answer: Hi, hi, hi, hi, hi, hi.

question: What?
answer: Okay.

question: Can we please go? It's going to be okay. I'm you're dad, you know? So it will be okay. You and I will make it okay. You ever ridden in a plane before?
answer: Yesssss! Don't stare at me.

question: Sorry.
answer: I want to put on my yellow dress now.

question: It's underneath the plane. We can't get it.
answer: I want to put on my dress. I want to put on my dress.

question: There's no way we can get the dress-- it's impossible. Don't kick the seat!
answer: I want the yellow dress. Give me a compromise.

question: As soon as we land. That's the compromise. God, I didn't hit her--she hit her.
answer: Noooooo. Let go of me. Noooo. The yellow dress... let go... let go.

question: Jeannie, we have to sit down. Please. I have no idea what to do. Jeannie, you okay?
answer: These are the wrong jammies.

question: Okay... so what do we do?
answer: Where do I sleep?

question: I have a sleeping bag and bed. Which one do you want?
answer: That. Hug. Let go.

question: Monica--is Leslie up yet? Good. I didn't want you to get worried when you realized I wasn't there. I'm still with that man. I'll tell you about it later. But it's sure nice to have wobbly legs again. Look, today's recycling day for Leslie at school, so give her some empty cans... well, then dump some out for her! Tell her I had to leave real early for work and I'll pick her up at school myself to make up for it and we'll rent any cassette she wants for tonight. Thank you... Take good care.
answer: Oh, I thought you took off in the middle of the night.

question: No. I just had to call home. Is that why you're sad?
answer: No. It's Everett. This kid who used to work for me. He was always crazy to do his own movie.

question: What happened?
answer: His movie not only opened to a three million dollar Friday--it's gotten great reviews. Listen. I'm tremendously worried about 'Ground Zero' because of the bad 'want to sees' you sent over. But that's just me being nervous over nothing, isn't it?

question: How're you doing? I'm from next door. I see you with your kids in the laundry room...
answer: Hello. ...Who are you?

question: Say, 'Hello, I'm your new neighbor now too.'
answer: I'm Lucy Crisala... What's your name?

question: Say, 'Jeannie.'
answer: I have a little girl too.

question: Say, 'Isn't that nice... How old is she?'
answer: She's four and a half and I have a little boy who is not yet one year.

question: Say, 'That's nice... I'd like to play with them... My Daddy didn't know your phone number, so we just decided to...'
answer: What can I do for you?

question: Say 'Daddy has to go to work tonight and...' I need someone to help me and her on short notice. I've seen your around with your kids and hoped you knew someone in the building or close by. I've got this new job that starts now. Do you know anyone?
answer: Well, I'm always here. I could maybe do it myself.

question: Oh, this is so great. Let's work out a full-time schedule and...
answer: Wait. Jeannie, why don't you come in for a minute and meet Ricky and Essa. Come on, we're making fruit bars. Why don't you leave her for a while and then we talk.

question: Sort of a test?
answer: We'll just see how it works.

question: Please behave, understand? I don't know what we'll do if this doesn't work, so behave, sweetheart. Behave, behave. I'm sorry I bothered you. Jeannie...
answer: Could I have her a little bit longer? My little boy just fell and Jeannie is the only one he let hold him.

question: Don't worry. My daughter used to throw fits in supermarkets when we first moved here. It's all so perfectly normal. Plus I know a great psychiatric children's group.
answer: That's what breaks your heart. Jeannie's problem is that she's so down on herself.

question: Well, she's lucky to have a daddy who cares, believe me.
answer: I don't know if lucky's the word. I'm hoping she's asleep when I get home so I won't have to deal with her... I'm actually afraid of my own kid.

question: Oh, yes. He's excited, but only because he sees glory for himself in it... See, ordinarily I wouldn't say that about my doctor, but I can't help it, it's the truth. He's monitoring me for a while longer before writing it up for this medical journal...
answer: Burke's going crazy waiting for the score.

question: Coming.
answer: How are you, anyway? It's a tough one, huh? Me too.

question: What, in God's name, are you doing in this job you have? I mean him. What, in God's name, do you know about casting?
answer: Me?

question: Yes. What do you know? About anything? You don't even know you have a habit of touching your tongue with a finger like you want to lick yourself. Yet, you talk like you actually know something... So I want you to tell me... ...what you know.
answer: I'm not going to be drawn into this.

question: Oh, you couldn't be more wrong. And I'm not talking to you. And I don't like you.
answer: How about you just mind your own business?

question: You're minding my business. That's the problem... so, just tell me, what do you know? Just tell me and I'll shut up.
answer: First of all, I've been going to movies since I was six, for God's sake...

question: What you know is the size of a schnozz. What you don't know is that these guys... ...are for real... ...that they can make something happen, and even they don't know what that is till they get in there and play a little... they can make something happen that you can't even imagine... and it's not your fault, this stupidity... 'cause you're just this scared little prick who gets to say he's making movies, and the only thing they ever taught you is that what you like doesn't matter.
answer: Thanks for understanding.

question: You look down.
answer: I am.

question: Thank you. I appreciate the support.
answer: I'm not down for you. I'm down about myself.

question: Oh. What if 'Ground Zero' doesn't do well this weekend?
answer: Please listen to me.

question: What?
answer: I just got this feeling of seeing myself talking to you and how this is the most important moment of... ever.

question: Okay. Good. What is it?
answer: I've been watching this company make movies that cost tens of millions of dollars and all the while I've known about this wonderful script which we can somehow own and we could make for about $14,000,000... $3,000,000 if you can live without stars or a name director.

question: Is that it? Okay, send me...
answer: I've sent you coverage on it nine times. I swear to you, Burke, it will work. You've never heard me say that.

question: How about last night?
answer: I don't know anything about action- adventure!! I have no idea where that came from. Hey, I know everyone thinks I don't have any commercial sense because of what I said at the 'Gremlins' preview and all... And you think I can't put myself on the line. Well, if this picture doesn't work, fire me. Have me killed if it doesn't get good reviews. If this doesn't get a 70 percent definite recommend from women 49 and under, I promise to be your sex slave until they drop ticket prices back to five bucks and start enforcing the R rating.

question: You're selling very excellent. Very excellent presentation.
answer: You've got to do this. I think this movie can save me.

question: Oh, please... What's the script?
answer: 'Mr. Deeds Goes to Town.'

question: Why couldn't you even look at the way I dressed Ricky?
answer: Look, I don't want to talk about it. I just had a real rough day... so just let it sit there, okay?

question: But what was it? Tellll me... Compromise... You sad?
answer: Yes. Now, I really need to be quiet.

question: You!! I know what will cheer you up. I can't even remember the words... I am stupid.
answer: No, you're not. You're not stupid and I'm not bitter... and you know why? Because there's no cure for either one and we've got to believe in some cure for each of us.

question: I am stupid. I can't even remember the words to some baby song.
answer: Oh, Jeannie... I just can't do this now. Hello? Yes. Cathy... Hey. Just a second. Jeannie, please... be quiet for one second... this is very important for me. So? Wow. Good for you. Congratulations. Me? This is great. I'll come right over and pick up the script. Okay. If you want to. Bring it over. Goodbye. We might make it yet, kid.

question: Well,... thank you.
answer: Thanks.

question: What a little winner, huh?
This is my favorite project. And it looks like we're going ahead with it.
answer: 'Mr. Deeds Goes to Town?' Oh, it's a remake...

question: Well, come on, what's original? And this is a wonderful rewrite. It's funnier.
answer: And there's a part in it for...

question: Yes... Burke says I can test whoever I want. He wasn't even surprised when I mentioned you. So, if you could read this rewrite now and if you like it, we can make a test deal... they can make a test deal... we can tell them that they can make a test deal. I think it's important for me to steer clear of the business end.
answer: Okay... which part?

question: Longfellow Deeds.
answer: Mr. Deeds?

question: Who goes to town, yes.
answer: Who are we kidding? I'm even having trouble getting short parts--I'm going to say I love it no matter what you've done to it.

question: Why not? If you can test movies and premises and want-to-sees, why can't you test screen tests?
answer: I can't deal with your self-centered dribble right now. I have just had the biggest orgasm of my life and I'm trying to figure out if I'm in love with you.

question: What?
answer: Whoops. Tell me what made you rush over and pick me up and bring me here at six o'clock. I mean we seem to have... ...this unspoken agreement not to talk about why we're together when we're together and I don't think it's good to let that become a pattern for us.

question: Why did I rush to you? Because I felt like I had to... be with someone and you were closest. What's wrong?
answer: You're not at all aware that you've just said something... ...unattractive?

question: Look, I'm sorry if that came out...
answer: I'm not looking for an apology.

question: I'm just trying to say that one of the things I'm not great at is...
answer: Let's not make this about your shortcomings. I'm sure you've had enough of those conversations to last you a lifetime. What I'm...

question: No, I haven't.
answer: No, you haven't what?

question: Had a conversation about shortcomings...
answer: No woman has ever told you that you have an almost barbaric insensitivity? That you seem to have lapsed into some final cynicism, where you actually believe that, not only does everyone think the way you do, but only you have the courage to express it? That you seem horribly certain everyone else is sort of pretending when they talk about love or seem to care for anything outside their own anus? No one's ever said that sort of thing to you?

question: Oh, yeah... But I didn't get what you meant by 'shortcomings.' Hey, if you think things like that, what are you doing here?
answer: I'm here for the same reason 86 percent of older women loved 'Beauty and the Beast.' I would like to believe that underneath the creature, there is a sweet, caring guy.

question: I sure hope you're wrong.
answer: I have to pick up Leslie.

question: I mistimed it. I wanted you to catch me fully frontal. So you loved it. A lot? A little?
answer: Give me a second--all of a sudden, there's a lot to deal with. It's terrific.

question: Do you see why I think you're right?
answer: Because you're nice and you know I need work.

question: You know this is really happening, so I wish you wouldn't kid around about it.
answer: Sorry, but I think the audition rule is that I have to be serious unless the person in charge is wearing a bathrobe and her nipples are sticking out... ...this much.

question: There are some mixed signals coming out of here, aren't there? Hi. Working... I can't write down a number now. Call me back. The script?
answer: It's really good. I get a little nervous thinking about the opportunity.

question: I want to hear everything. You want to go page by page?
answer: If it's okay. I kind of work on these things in a private... it's just... it's a little better for me if I don't...

question: Okay.
answer: Okay, let's do it. It won't kill me.

question: Please. I understand.
answer: I swear to God, I don't know which thing I want more, the sex or the conversation afterwards.

question: What do you mean?
answer: I mean I haven't been to bed with anyone since Jeannie got here... I haven't talked to anyone the way I need to. I haven't seen anything this beautiful. I haven't felt this good about life. I mean, I've been lonely, Cathy.

question: I'll tell you the truth, Matt. I've never felt more like turning my phone off.
answer: You can't shut the phone off. I left this number with Jeannie's sitter.

question: I don't understand what you're worried about.
answer: I'm not worried. But if the phone was off, I would worry.

question: But I get a lot of calls.
answer: Oh.

question: I could put the machine on 'monitor,' but it's going to be... I don't know.
answer: It will be okay. I think the most important thing is to stop talking about the phone. Turn it off, monitor, whatever.

question: Okay. You look so serious.
answer: I am so serious. Is this the kind of crap you listen to all day?

question: Is there a name for what we just had? This is awkward, my driving you around and testing for you tomorrow.
answer: Not really.

question: Well, I hope you understand I can't drive you to work tomorrow and then go in and test. It's just...
answer: Okay. I was going to come in late anyway. I'll get one of the kids to drive me.

question: Thanks. And, look, if I get the lead in this movie, you'll have to go back to sitting up front with me. No sitter!!! Thanks. We're leaving now.
answer: Jeannie's fine. There's a whole bunch of kids in the building. She's fascinated. And they're all ready for you.

question: How many men are they testing today?
answer: You're the only one.

question: Then tell them I need a little more time. I mean for me. I want to focus a little.
answer: Sure. Good luck, Matt. The thing they're looking for most is sexy.

question: You wait here, Jeannie. I have to talk to you.
answer: Don't!

question: What in hell is wrong with you? You actually think...
answer: I'm trying to hang in here but everything in me cuts off when somebody acts this way.

question: ...that you can have my kid audition for a show without asking me.
answer: I didn't... She went for water and by the time she got back, they had offered her the part. Blame Burke, he was there...

question: What's the part, anyway?
answer: The white kid in a multi-racial foster home with all these kids of varying ages. It's not a bad show. I sure can't wait to see the test.

question: How were they able to test her so fast?
answer: No. They offered it to her off the reading. I meant your test.

question: Oh... A child actor. Just what any kid with problems needs to straighten out--a series of her own... You'll let me know as soon as they see my test?
answer: Right away... You've got my vote.

question: I'm doing it.
answer: Not if I don't let you. That's the law, the police law.

question: Do I have to learn to read to be on television?
answer: You're going to have to learn to look at me and listen to me and the longer I have to wait THE ANGRIER

question: I'm so mad.
answer: Me too. Just listen.

question: I don't... why?!?
answer: Because I know about this. I have worked with kid actors... They don't have that much fun. They're inside all day... they don't get to go to regular schools or play with their regular friends like Ricky and Essa. And their parents? You think I'm going to be one of those parents, sitting in one of those rooms, where we all go crazy trying to jump start our egos with our kids' sweat, all the time smiling at each other like our lives are working while we root against everyone else's little girl? No!! No way! I can't!

question: Okay. So, no, you're cuckoo anyway. I won't do it. And I don't care because I'm be stupid at it anyway.
answer: Pick it up, Jeannie. Let's work on it.

question: C'mon, Deeds, tell me about the meeting.
answer: What's wrong?

question: Don't worry about my crying. As a matter of fact, crying turns me on.
answer: Well, in that case, your dog died.

question: What happened at the meeting?
answer: I can't remember. You're too pretty. Oh, I told them I'd keep on being Chairman. I'm Chairman, you know.

question: I know.
answer: Told them I'd keep on being Chairman if they hired everybody back.

question: What did they say?
answer: Oh, that I was crazy. You always wear your hair back like that?

question: Very fuckable. Okay... that's her... What about him?
answer: I think he's a very good to excellent actor--I do... But there's something...

question: You wouldn't want to fuck him?
answer: Well, six years ago, maybe.

question: So you'd want to fuck him?
answer: The man is talented. If you get one of those directors who like actors, I think...

question: A director can't make you hot if you're not hot. You'll end up with warm which is death.
answer: We laughed.

question: Let me ask you something... Would you fuck him?
answer: Everything doesn't boil down to...

question: Let me stop you before you embarrass yourself. We all can do our little lectures on what things boil down to. Everybody else here was professional enough to come out and say... I'd fuck her... I wouldn't fuck him... and you're ducking it... I want you to forget the acting stuff and totally focus on the issue. We do have some kind of responsibility to the audience... You just saw his screentest... so, if this is the first time you saw the guy, do you come out thinking to yourself and your girl friends, 'I'd sure go to bed with him; oh God, would he be something.' Would you, Cathy?... I'm being real here.
answer: No...

question: Okay, so let's keep looking.
answer: Hello. Matt... Hi... Okay, sure... Matt... Matt... Matt... Maybe it would be easier if I just said 'hi' to her... Hi, Jeannie... Yes, it's exciting... No, no. He's right, honey, they get somebody to read it to you. Now, put your dad on--it's important. No, first put your dad on... DAMN IT! ...Matt. Uh-huh, a few hours ago... They all... everyone liked your work, but I think they'll go for a name or something. It's not a matter of doing it differently... they liked what you did, a lot... they laughed and... it's not you... it's them. No, please. Don't thank me. If you feel like getting together later or anytime, call me, okay? You sound like you have your hands full right now... Goodbye.

question: 'I don't think you have to worry about that?'
answer: Did we do well with any group at all?

question: Eleven-year-old boys in the South. Burke? Burke? Matt, is he...
answer: I'll see you later. Goodbye.

question: But, hon...
answer: I'm all alone... At least there's that.

question: I'm all alone... At least there's that.
answer: Are you going to need me? The kids are rehearsing and I'd like to take a look.

question: Yeah, sure. I have to stay inside during lunch hours now anyway--that's when everybody returns my calls because they're trying to miss me.
answer: Is that true?

question: I bet I know what it looks like to you.
answer: What?

question: A giant "find Waldo."
answer: Very funny. Set?

question: That pretend living room, right over there.
answer: Okay. Set. Bye...

question: Wait a second, Jeannie. Let Daddy give you a few tips here.
answer: Nooo. I've got to get to work. Is this the set?

question: I'm glad I found you.
answer: Hi.

question: You holding up? What did you do last night after I called?
answer: What do you think I did? I cried like a baby.

question: Okay. Okay. So you don't want to tell me. Be a tough guy.
answer: Now you got it.

question: I feel relieved just seeing you after all that stuff... whew... Okay. Burke wants to...
answer: You ever go out with him?

question: Yes.
answer: You slept with him?

question: Yes.
answer: Did you hate it?

question: Eventually.
answer: Good Lord.

question: That's all?!? This isn't going to be good.
answer: Not with that attitude. It's just that they... Well, did they tell you what an audience is?

question: I know what an audience is.
answer: Good. Now, because there's an audience, they want you to know all the words you have to say really well. And since you can't read yet... ...you're going to have to be patient and try hard. I can help you.

question: Can you help me to cry?
answer: Yes. I can. I can help make it okay. Trust me.

question: I miss my mother bigger than you know.
answer: Not yet. Don't grab. Thank you. We really appreciate this. Hi, Beth. I...

question: Mom? No... Nothing... Nothing... Nothing. Nothing... Would you talk? I'd just like to listen to you... Wait. Let me sit down. Dad says he's going to make me to really cry.
answer: Jeannie, your mom's not going to understand what you mean.

question: She understands!!! He's being terrible right now. I love, loved, the coloring book you sent me. Goodbye. Wait. I love you. Let me hang up first. Love you. Send me a letter. Bye. And a beaded T- shirt. Bye.
answer: Why don't you let me be on your side for a second?

question: I can't even understand what you're saying now.
answer: Do you know what trust means?

question: Not very.
answer: It means that even if something is hard to believe, you believe someone you trust because you know he wouldn't say it unless it were true.

question: I understand. So I don't trust anybody, right?
answer: Yeah, I think you get the concept.

question: You don't make sense. I don't understand you.
answer: I think you do. Just know that...

question: Okayyyy!
answer: You want to help me make a phone call? Seven... two...

question: Who are we calling?
answer: Cathy. She's very nice. One... six...

question: Jeannie... I can't talk now because...
answer: Wait, my dad wants to...

question: Tell him I can't talk 'cause I'm on the phone with a director...
answer: He wants to talk to you very much and...

question: We look like jerks eating here this early. Everybody's going to think we couldn't get a reservation for the hot hours.
answer: Why do you do this to yourself? Why do you insist on eating dinner in a restaurant where you're bound to see all the people you're afraid of?

question: I'm not afraid of them.
answer: What do you call it when you think that what a group of people think of you can confirm or destroy any decent idea you have of yourself?

question: Normal.
answer: How did little Jeannie do today?

question: Isn't it something that they have you testing the TV show?
answer: What I asked was, how did Jeannie do?

question: What are you talking about?
answer: Somebody else. Jeannie. How did she do?

question: Don't talk to me like this.
answer: I want to be treated as if I'm really saying words to you which you engage and respond to. I like Matt; I'd like to know how his daughter did. So before you take your dance of desperation across the restaurant and I end up feeling so sorry for you that I could die, I would like you to answer my question.

question: She did okay... and don't worry about Matt... If the pilot sells, his kid will be making five thousand a week. So what do you know about 'People Get Hurt?'
answer: I'm told that they're not going to release it...

question: I knew. I knew. What the hell are you smiling for?
answer: Forgive me. But telling you about this latest failure of yours--it pleases me. I have no idea why.

question: I can't be with someone who's not rooting for me.
answer: I think I am. It's just that rooting for you is a good deal more complicated than you realize. Don't go.

question: Don't worry. I'm not that mad. I gotta do this. Sorry. I thought you were someone else. Nan, you know Victor and his wife... and Jay and his wife...
answer: Yes. I'm sorry I can't talk now. I'm very upset about what's happening to Burke, so I just made up my mind I can't be witness to it anymore if I love him and I certainly shouldn't be here if I don't... so I was just in the process of leaving when he stopped me and you folks walked in... I'm sure you've had something like this happen to you some time... some horrible thing in your personal life happening in public. Thank you for understanding. Goodbye. I wish only good things for you even though I feel I've been really damaged by this relationship.

question: Thank you. Thank you. We're very close.
answer: You don't understand that I'm exhausted from hurting. I'm through with you.

question: I don't know if I've been bad. I know somebody's been bad. ...maybe it's you. Oh, I love you so much, I love you so much... I love you so much.
answer: I hope that makes you feel a whole lot better, Chile... 'Cause it sure goes a long way to cure what ails me.

question: I can't believe I...
answer: ...got in this much...

question: ...got in this much trouble. .
answer: Right. Over a...

question: Word?
answer: Yes. 'I can't believe I got in this much trouble over a word.' Now do you know what she means when she says that?

question: I don't want to talk about it--just say her stuff so I know mine.
answer: No. It's your choice... But I'm not helping unless you try to understand as well as memorize. It will be fun. Come on. I know it's hard...

question: Okay. Okay...
answer: Anything to shut me up, huh? Okay, this little girl you're pretending to be... she can't be with her Mommy either, just like you, or her father... she has to stay in Rainbow House which is called that because... Jeannie... ...because everyone's a different color... so when this little girl calls the black lady who takes care of all the children this terrible word... it's like the worst thing anybody can do... Come here.

question: I don't want to do the 'I love you' again.
answer: Yeah, I might have been working you too hard on that one.

question: Yeah. Why don't you do that with poopie Cathy?
answer: Now, did the director tell you how he wanted you to do it?

question: He said to smile all the time almost and to talk... uh...
answer: Faster?

question: Yes.
answer: Okay. We don't always get good directors, so it's important for us...

question: Me. You're not in the show.
answer: I'm referring to the family of actors, you little shithead.

question: This is so good...
answer: It's a breakfast burrito. It's what actors eat when they're working.

question: Really.
answer: Now, let's work a little more. The most important acting you do is when you listen. You're worried about being able to cry when you're supposed to, right?

question: Yes. So much.
answer: Well, there are really only two ways to do it. Think of something that makes you really sad... or forget you're you and really forget you're pretending...

question: How do I do that one?
answer: 'Don't test me, child! I could eat you for lunch when I was your age and I'm a hell of a lot bigger now!' That's it... You just looked at me and acted right without even thinking. And there are games you can play to help you with this. Get up... Now, be my mirror... do exactly what I do... that's it... now, at a certain point, I'm going to become your mirror, but I'm not going to tell you when... you tell me...

question: Now?
answer: Okay. We're going to make up words. The words aren't what matter now.

question: I'm on a roof...
answer: You're a great dad.

question: You're a... Okay.
answer: You're welcome. Don't mention it. I'm a free man. Let's go to your house and break the answering machine.

question: You're welcome. Don't mention it. I'm a free man. Let's go to your house and break the answering machine.
answer: You know, I could get away now. But I've got a big meeting later. We'd better take two cars. See you later. Thanks again.

question: I hope it's you. So this is how the big ones make out. What's the matter?
answer: I don't know whether I'm being a coward for telling you this way or brave for telling you period... Can you hear me?

question: Yes.
answer: But I better talk fast because this is where my phone always kicks out... When we did your screentest... Can you hear me?

question: Yes.
answer: Well, I sort of folded on you at the end. Matt?

question: You didn't like what I did?
answer: I did. Truly. But the discussion got sort of dumb. It was a question of sexiness.

question: That's what it came down to?
answer: Well, sort of, yes.

question: You folded on whether or not I'm sexy. You don't think I'm sexy... and you expressed that to...
answer: Well, I'll tell you. I certainly must think so pretty much because I feel great about where we're going now... Are you very mad at me?

question: Hello.
answer: Hi, Matt, this is Burke. I'm sorry to bother you at home, but you know Nan... We were going out a little and I could use another guy's slant on what's just happened.

question: I don't think I can get into this...
answer: Why? Did I catch you at a bad time?

question: Worse. You caught me at a bad time you caused.
answer: Oh, you mean about the screentest. The whole room thought you did good work.

question: Thanks.
answer: Yeah, look, I'm not going to bother you about my thing.

question: Jeannie. Just remember. You're not even here tonight. There's only this other little girl that you're pretending to be who lives at Rainbow House.
answer: ...and who just vomited. I just found out that we bow before we even do anything.

question: Great.
answer: And everybody claps.

question: Great.
answer: I made up a great bow. You going to look?

question: Wouldn't miss it.
answer: I'm not going to be able to cry. It's too hard for me.

question: Matt. Matt. Matt.
answer: I don't want to miss her introduction.

question: I'll talk fast. It's amazing news. Oliver Stone's been looking for a comedy and...
answer: I've got to see my kid.

question: ...he's doing my picture.
answer: Hey. Good.

question: Part of this involves you. He remembers you from 'Platoon' and wants to use you in this one. Got your attention, huh?
answer: Oh, Cathy. Look, I'm going to watch this. Let me talk to you later or tomorrow. Thanks for your help. It's good news. Gotta go. Shit.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Why couldn't you wait till later? Shit.

question: I guess it's because I'm just incredibly insensitive to all human needs. I'd ask you to save me, but I'm so far gone, I wouldn't want you to waste your time.
answer: Huh?

question: You little stinker!
answer: You big stinker.

question: My little stinker.
answer: My big stinker.

question: Amazing, right?
answer: Thank you. That's nice.

question: You look happy.
answer: I loved it, Daddy.

question: You want me to put you down?
answer: No. This is okay.

question: Okay... Now, you're not finished until you hug the lady just like you did me. I'm very proud of you. I love you more than anybody.
answer: When I had to cry, I thought of you buried in the ground.

question: It's the first time they had me do cards for a pilot and the demographics are all wrong for after nine o'clock. That's their only opening. Hi. I'm Nan. I'm a good friend of your Dad's.
answer: Hello, Nan. I'm Jeannie. Did you see it?

question: Yes, and you were wonderful. 89 percent likeability. And knowing that you were that good means so much more than the show not going.
answer: What?

question: Oh, no. I couldn't help it.
answer: What does she mean? What do you mean? What does she mean? What do you mean?

question: What does she mean? What do you mean? What does she mean? What do you mean?
answer: That they're not going to be doing any more of these shows right now-- but...

question: Oh, my God.
answer: Honey...

question: And that means they're not going to have a party?
answer: No. They're still having the party.

question: Oh... really?... good... can we stay late?
answer: Honey, we're going to close the place.

question: I'm not comfortable with television anyway... it's too small... I'm much better at something with size... I don't do itzy. Even this movie of Cathy's--it's small... medium small. But with Stone it takes on a certain volume where I start to feel comfortable. I hate my life... ...in a way. I had a drink in my office. I'm confused. You're not saying anything. Is it because you're not listening or because I haven't stopped talking?
answer: This Oliver Stone thing... does he really want me?

question: Yeah. Oh, yeah. I forgot to say congratu...
answer: Which part?

question: Which one you want?
answer: One of the two leads wouldn't be bad.

question: No. It's the crippled factory owner.
answer: Best part in the movie.

question: Wait a second.
answer: I want to see my kid.

question: A second--look, they're taking the cast picture now anyway. She doesn't look anything like the women I usually go with. And you know what they say, "beauty fades." What they don't say is that it fades very slowly.
answer: You don't think I can tell you what to do?

question: No. Only I can do that. I want you to tell me what to feel... Look. I trust her. More important, everyone does. You have no idea how impressed people are with her. She's smart. She's interesting. You never know what she'll say next... Her work is amazing. I like talking to her. You have no idea what to expect next. I respect what she does more than any writer or director--sincerely-- much more unusual--much more important. So?
answer: Good luck.

question: Dance with me. On a business basis.
answer: No. But I'll dance with you because I think it will reassure me that I should have nothing to do with you.

question: I'll take it.
answer: Why are you breathing so heavy?

question: Nervous... Look, let's move our thing in a more regular direction.
answer: What do you mean?

question: Let me think. What if we go out this weekend... ...with your kid.
answer: ...whose name is?

question: Whose name is... Leslie.
answer: Okay.
